results:
Based on the search results, I found detailed information about the first Polish translation of "Robinson Crusoe" and its 18th-century history. Here's what I discovered:

The first Polish translation of "Robinson Crusoe" was commissioned by King Stanisław August Poniatowski and was done by Bishop Jan Chrzciciel Albertrandi, published in 1769 under the title "Przypadki Robinsona Kruzoe. Z angielskiego języka na francuski przełożone i skrócone od p. Feutry, teraz ojczystym językiem wydane" (Cases of Robinson Crusoe. Translated from English to French and shortened by Mr. Feutry, now published in the native language). This was published in Warsaw in volumes 1-2, with a second edition in Lviv in 1774.(no content)This translation was based on a simplified French version, which was a common practice at the time - many Polish translations of foreign works in the 18th century were made through French intermediary translations rather than directly from the original language.

It took Polish readers over 300 years to get the first complete edition of Robinson Crusoe in Polish, highlighting how the original 18th-century translation was incomplete or adapted.

Recently, the first complete three-volume Polish edition was published by Ossolineum in the Biblioteka Narodowa series, as the fact that Defoe's novel consists of three volumes was never widely known. This new edition is one of the few complete adaptations in the world, emphasizing the historical significance of that first 18th-century Polish translation attempt.

The 1769 translation represents an important milestone in Polish literary history, being one of the early examples of English literature being made available to Polish readers during the Enlightenment period under King Stanisław August Poniatowski's cultural patronage.
